ï»¿Execution Version - Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Inf -astructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is enlered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) STANDARD CHARTERED BANK herein represented by its Group Executive Director and (:EJ) for EMEA and Americas, and headquartered in England at 1 Basinghall Avenue, London, E C: 5DD, UK ("Standard Chartered"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPIV Eh ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, US \ le INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvan Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC C 33, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Interl EIti: nal Organizations (lOs), the G77, and the private sector represented by the B20 that investin I r :he infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to ::p ind access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic r vth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on 1.ng sources of infrastructure finance-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coor:i: :ed effort is needed to mobilize private sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robust pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects anc ii is understood to be the greatest barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm( r 1: (D) Governments, development finance institutions, donors, and private investors share an int 4. t in developing the market for private infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand i:. in the numbers of structurally scund and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual em( - c ice of EMDE infrastructure as a ecognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range of Fr ate investors that actively particiiate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will ter efit from collective action between this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowli! . to find solutions to complex irfrastructure financing challenges that no single institutioi c: uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure F a: lity Partnership Program ("GIF"). The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leverac ir C the efforts of the wide range of irstitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructi ra iith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prepi 1 on, structuring, and risk mitigation for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, 'i 31F aims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supported I hj the Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepe - . ell- structured, infrastructure projects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for acces< it C the expertise of the Parties and other GIF partners, in combination with guidance from pro, , : :ive private sector financiers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater lE e ige of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular f :I rge and complex projects with thE: potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interes:ed in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure F; ility Partnership Program, togethEr with other partners. 2
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have come to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended to be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set o t in Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the 3IF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collat :on on, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and A it other potential partners until the GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje:; ii s and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to work together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to further enhance their coordination, in particular by developing tI E C IF, with a view to formally establishing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foregoing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue tc collaborate in developing the 31F, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the roles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categor, b. Governance arrangements of the GIF; c. Operational policies applicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activities and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to projE:. selection criteria and coordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of :.ollaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includ i; sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through th . u! a of knowledge platfornis for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finalizing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bank: li! ted in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF dE si is finalized, additional collaborative efforts are required to develop the operational details f :i the GIF, at all times complementing existing efforts and facilities and building upon the s3 ,1: ed knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the e,': of coordination between the Parties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Arrangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment Il le Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commoi i understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose al I: gal obligations or liabilities on any Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Arrangement is valid and effective for a period of one year from ti: date thereof, unless superseded at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect that this document and information with respect to the collabor 11 activities contemplated herein will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' iespective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult witl h 3
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppor regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arrang ament will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatic nc other modification of any of the privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th( Parties under their constitueni documents, international conventions and any applicable la)! In witness whereof, each of the Part es has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execute:I in two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a! ,i he date first set forth above. 4
ï»¿Execution Version STAND DCHARTERED BANK By: MR. V. SHANKAR, GROUP EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND CEO FOR EMEA & AMERICj ,; 5
ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIOl i A D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: JI N IM, PRESIDENT 6
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the G IF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pr.: e: :s in emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatic r provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial - n: institutional investor engagerrent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex public-private partnerships and projects with potential for commer :il viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastrui t1 financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coord n: )n resources in collaboration with the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of the F/ e range of donor and development finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDI infrastructure, with the input a!d ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemer I ::. Old stretch from upstream suppori on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to downstream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemeni. 1.3 Over the longer term, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structurel I infrastructure projects, the Gil: can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset class attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long-:( r assets in faster growing economies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profile 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to operate according to the following core principles, to be finalize:I ul on agreement among GIF partners: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities thi ' II draw together comparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing public goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly those infrastructure projects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting susteainability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to b:!!t practice standards for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizirig te:: n al and financial rescurces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mul il di ral development institutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greate leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resources of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected :o involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t1'= development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF pa ti s are expected to fall into one cr more of the following categories: 7
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partners-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wil IE considered Fundi'ig Partners. (ii) Technical Partne rs-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice and support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde, I activities and/or p-ovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppo t instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sovereign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as we I other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure projects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparat on optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inves:ment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Coincil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmin, management and use of fund:, and development of operational policies and procedures; an hold the GIF Management Unit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, wit advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compoE it ci of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propc s:!: to comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Council comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing DirE: and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilit:. e coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve :i . sounding board, providing guidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wi i E view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be administered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate( i -n established for this purpose (the GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fu it n as a coordinating body as prciects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mov:! toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead inc iI dial projects. 4.2 GIF activity implemertation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partne institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governmei it I according to specific project requirements and the project origination processes. Composi ii of the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and gove n, r nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follov i principles: (i) Development Irimpact-projects that support the development goals of the GI partner institutions; (ii) Alignment-projects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities : strategies; (iii) Complexity-projects that require multiple parties to come together to providl structuring, arranging and financial support, and/or projects which require a bl I ic f financial instruments; and 8
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact -projects that have significant potential to achieve financial i :l: lity, leverage public fLnds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- w I as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's ser/ice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastructure investments that have global public good characteristic c. ich as climate friendly-projects that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provision cf infrastructure services; and tride enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconne:i i and trade. 5.2 The scope of support provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with i v w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and oti F funding mechanisms. During :he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac ) 1i is, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; project definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr , ig; and legal, regulatbry, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparaticn and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PPP structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangiig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi I packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-including in particular the management of environmental and oc il impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastri c tu e projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements external implementing entitie; under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards anc (t ,r standards and policies, and develop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GI= Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 9
ï»¿Execution Version Annex 2 Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) and their Respective Project Preparation Resources and Initiatives During the process of finalizing the design of the GIF, the following MDBs will be invited to partici tI as initial Technical Partners. The operalional details for the GIF will at all times complement the i is ng efforts and facilities of these MDBs, which include but are not limited to the infrastructure I-o 3ct preparation resources and initiatives Isted below: a. African Developmerit Bank (AfDB) - NEPAD Infrastructure Project Preparation F:1: lity (NEPAD-IPPF) as well as the project development business segment of Africa 10 nd various support effort: for Africa-focused PPFs; b. Asian Development Bank (ADB) - Office of Public-Private Partnership and its pr :ip ed Asia Pacific Project :reparation Facility ('AP3F') as well as several dedicated r Eli: 1al PPFs; c. European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) - Legai Tnr si on Programme, and the proposed EBRD Infrastructure Project Preparation Facility ('ll I) d. European Investment Bank (EIB) - European PPP Expertise Centre (EPEC): e. Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) - 'InfraFund' project preparation facili y' f. Islamic Development Bank (IsDB) - Arab Financing Facility for Infrastructure TE:i cal Assistance Facility (AFFI TAF), co-managed with the International Finance Corr c r,I ion (IFC); and g. World Bank Group (WBG) comprising the International Bank for Reconstruct): ind Development (IBRD) the International Development Association (IDA), the Inten E:i: nal Finance Corporation :IFC), and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MI' ! 10
